posts.title: La mujer sin cabeza
posts.excerpt: Quote: “I feel a little … I don’t feel good.” So says Veronica, the middle-aged upper-middle-class Argentinean woman who suffers a nasty bump on the noggin early on in Lucrecia Martel’s The Headless Woman (La Mujer Sin Cabeza) and spends the rest of the movie in a semiconscious stupor, a stranger in her own body. …

posts.excerpt: Synopsis: “Like his fiery study of a popular milieu in Fièvre, Louis Delluc’s early masterpiece of impressionist cinema, La Femme de Nulle Part, is almost impossible to see outside of rare archival projections in Paris. posts.title: Bulanti
posts.excerpt: Quote: Ahmet, a prominent intellectual, lost his wife and daughter in a traffic accident which happened while he was spending the night with his lover. posts.title: Fantômes
posts.excerpt: Quote: On the surface, Jean-Paul Civeyrac’s Fantômes unfolds with a sense of haunted, supernatural disequilibrium that similarly infuses Kiyoshi Kurosawa’s atmospheric, tonal cinema. In the film’s opening sequence, a young acting student, Mouche (Dina Ferreira) stares out the window of an empty room and wistfully implores her absent lover, Bruno (Olivier Boreel) to return. posts._title: Pedro Costa – Cavalo Dinheiro AKA Horse Money (2014)
posts.title: Cavalo Dinheiro
posts.excerpt: Quote: A phantasmagorical vision of psychological purgatory, Horse Money (Cavalo dinheiro) will enrapture some while leaving others dangling in frustrated limbo. Only the sixth fictional feature from Portuguese writer-director Pedro Costa in the quarter-century since his 1989 debut Blood, its austere opacity will convert few to the Costa cause. posts.title: Treasure Island
posts.excerpt: Raoul Ruiz’s surrealistic modern-day riff on Robert Louis Stevenson’s classic novel. Review by timmy_501 @IMDb: While this film is related to the Robert Louis Stevenson book of the same title, it certainly doesn’t resemble a traditional adaptation. posts._title: Claire Denis – L’intrus AKA The Intruder [+Extras] (2004)
posts.title: L’intrus
